questions.text: Child Language Development Analysis - Text A
model_answers: Beth uses labelling correctly 'froggie', albeit in a diminutive form.
Natasha responds to Danielle’s suggestions and builds on them. Charlie copies her.
Both children seem to enjoy playing with language and sound within the context of sending a message while wearing frog masks.
Element of performance.
Phonology: There is gliding/substitution from Charlie ‘/fw ɒg/’.
Phonology: Rhyming and repetition of ‘frog’ with a range of words/sounds initiated by Natasha and copied by Charlie.
Phonology: Natasha uses largely standard pronunciation; Charlie follows her lead and copies.
Grammar: Natasha uses subject and object pronouns correctly ‘do you miss me’; Charlie copies her.
Grammar: Syntactic parallelism used by Natasha: first person pronoun + verb, e.g. ‘I like froggie’.
Grammar: All of the children’s utterances are in the present tense.
Grammar: Use of concrete nouns – ‘froggie’, ‘logger’ [log], – reflecting topic/activity.
Grammar: Natasha sometimes omits auxiliary verbs ‘I little froggie cola’, but not always ‘I’m a little froggie’.
Grammar: Natasha uses standard syntax (e.g. subject-verb-object) appropriately ‘I like going on a loggy’.
Grammar: Natasha makes use of an interrogative, ‘do you miss me’, and declaratives, ‘I’m a little frog’.
Grammar: Use of ‘froggie’ as an adjective (‘froggie things’) as well as a noun.
Concepts: The mother’s interaction provides scaffolding (Bruner) and modelling (Skinner).
Concepts: Natasha creates neologisms, for example, ‘froggagola’.
Concepts: Mother uses imperative and interrogative functions to provide scaffolding.
Concepts: Naming words represent 60% of children's early word production (Nelson).
Concepts: Capacity for imaginative play suggests cognitive development (Piaget) and imaginative function of language (Halliday).
Concepts: Mention of Vygotsky’s ZPD – Danielle encouraging children to extend/adapt speech to message format.

questions.text: Language, Power and Gender Analysis - Text B
model_answers: Accompanying image of seven female students reflects the topic and suggests positive body language.
Interrogative headline ‘Are sexist attitudes still to blame…’ aligns writer with anti-sexist stance.
Goodman – informalisation features in the online article context.
Representation of (female) professor as successful disarms gender stereotypes (Pilkington).
Cameron – assumptions in education regarding females better suited to biology/medicine over physics.
Graphological features typical of genre (e.g., social media links).
Lexical fields of science and study: ‘heat-resistance experiment’, ‘A-level’, ‘experimental physics’.
Latinate/sophisticated lexical choices reflect broadsheet context (The Guardian).
Use of proper nouns/names to establish credibility/influential power (Fairclough), e.g., Athene Donald.
Use of numbers/statistics connotes instrumental power of auditing organisations.
Metaphor ‘champion’ for female physics professor suggests context of an ongoing battle.
Noun phrases in apposition for naming participants: ‘Alice, a sixth-former at Lampton School’.
Pragmatics: Positioning in relation to clichéd expectations (Twilight, boy bands) is unclear/ironic.
Pragmatics: Focus on asymmetry in subject choices and encouraging females into science.
Pragmatics: Idiomatic reference to ‘a bit of stick’ as a euphemism for resistance girls face in physics.
Pragmatics: Use of Lampton School as a specific example to address asymmetry.
Semantic field of deterioration: ‘risk’, ‘slip’, ‘problem’.

questions.topic: Language Change: 19th vs 21st Century Volcano Reports (Text C and Text D)

conclusion: Comparison of the sense of individual writer (Text C) vs neutral historical view (Text D).
Analysis of how language has varied over time from 1868 to 2018 in terms of complexity and formality.
introduction: Text C: Letter to the editor of a local newspaper (1868) describing volcanic activity in South Hawaii; focus on impact on surroundings; precise but personal tone.
Text D: Online article from Hawaii Volcano Observatory (2018) informing readers about the 1868 eruption; historical view; neutral and impersonal.

text_c_points: Lends itself to multiple concrete nouns (crater, fissures, stream) known to local readership.
text_d_points: Concrete nouns (mountain, lava) and specialist lexis (décollement) with glossing.
Lexical field of conflict (damage, destroyed) and volcanoes.
Use of dramatic journalese: 'most deadly', 'destruction', 'volcanic crisis'.
Use of dates and numbers for specificity and measurement (magnitude 7.8).

text_c_points: Clause-laden sentences characteristic of the period.
Relative clauses used to provide additional information.
Active sentences foreground the writer’s role ('I descended'); passive voice used for volcanic impact.
Fronted adverbials: 'Of Hilo I have little to say' (archaic/quaint).
Intensifiers ('very') and superlatives ('most active') for precision.
text_d_points: Complex sentences with embedded clauses but less complexity than Text C.
Conditional 'If it happened today' to provide temporal context.
Modal auxiliary 'would' used for comparison with other events.
Proper nouns used throughout to reflect geographic focus.

text_c_points: Cohesion provided by letter format and chronological paragraphs.
Explicit engagement with the reader at the beginning.
Framed in terms of urgency ('I hasten') and status (referencing the local clergyman).
Passive voice represents the landscape at the mercy of the volcano.
text_d_points: Informative style with chronological structure and temporal discourse markers.
Short paragraphs characteristic of online articles.
Ending acts as summary and hook into subsequent articles.
Framing in relation to other historical earthquakes (1906 San Francisco) for context.
Use of jargon/glossing to meet informative purpose.
Juxtaposition of factual content with figurative language ('bounced like balls').
